Sandoz, Swinarski and Zimmermann (eds) (fn 3) paras 2257–58.\n© 2023 The Author Journal compilation © 2023 Edward Elgar Publishing Ltd Downloaded from https://www.elgaronline.com/ at 07/16/2025 08:36:46PM via University College London (UCL)</https:> The application of the principle of precautions to cyber operations 37 It has been claimed that while providing shelter may seem rational in traditional domains, its application in cyberspace is still unknown.²⁵¹ However, there are some measures which are applicable to cyberspace by analogy. For example, civilians might be supported by providing them with software products such as anti-virus programs that limit the damage from cyber attacks, detecting civilian cyber systems in order to warn people in case of intrusion attempts, providing them technical assistance when their computer systems are harmed, providing a back-up system to store civilian data, blocking particular IP addresses which pose risks to civilian systems, and keeping ready a system that makes it possible to disconnect an entire country from the Internet when all measures are exhausted.²⁵² While the title of Article 58 includes ‘attacks’, paragraph (c) clearly states that some precautions should be applied to operations. Although Jensen admits the ambiguity of this situation, he argues that countries which are not parties to the AP-I have responsibility arising from this provision for those acts that reach ‘attack’ threshold.²⁵³ In the Tallinn Manual, even though the majority of experts stated that the rule is applicable only to cyber attacks because of the title of the article and the non-existence of customary law, the minority focused on the wording of paragraph (c) by accepting cyber operations within the ambit of this rule.²⁵⁴ Therefore, the minority view kept the threshold lower, determined disruptive operations to be covered by this rule, and obligated parties to take precautions against the effects of these operations.²⁵⁵ However, both parties have a common understanding on the non-application of the rule to ‘mere inconvenience or irritation’.²⁵⁶ There is no clear-cut answer on which precautions should be taken within the ambit of Article 58(c), since the provision serves as a gap-filler in the article. Despite the fact that it did not receive much attention in the past because the suitability of other provisions for kinetic activities made them more visible than paragraph (c), their relative unsuitability for cyber operations rendered this clause more important. At this point, the implementation of the norm in cyberspace has already begun to be shaped by the practices of both state and non-state actors, and this trend seems to be continuing and getting better. Jensen (fn 58) 213.\n© 2023 The Author Journal compilation © 2023 Edward Elgar Publishing Ltd Downloaded from https://www.elgaronline.com/ at 07/16/2025 08:36:46PM via University College London (UCL) The application of the principle of precautions to cyber operations 35 infrastructures used for essential civilian purposes’.²³⁶ For example, parties to the conflict can build a separate cyber infrastructure in which only military communications travel through it, and locate dual-use cyber infrastructures separate from civilians.²³⁷ Although it can be claimed that situations may arise in which civilian and military networks cannot be segregated, state practice has started to follow a different pathway.²³⁸ It is stated by Walker that: In cyberspace, State practice, particularly that of the United States, makes clear that it is feasible to separate purely military objectives from civilian objectives, at least up to a point. The United States military uses multiple, dedicated networks to conduct administrative, logistical and operational activities. The three best-known networks are the Non-Classified Internet Protocol Router Network (NIPRnet, which carries information classified up to and including Sensitive but Unclassified), Secret Internet Protocol Router Network (SIPRnet, which carries data classified up to and including the Secret level) and the Joint Worldwide Intelligence Communication System (JWICS carries data classified up to and including Top Secret/Sensitive Compartmented Information).²³⁹ As this example clearly shows, it is imperative to segregate the different types of networks, even if it can be costly.²⁴⁰ Otherwise, if the object makes an effective contribution and the segregation cannot be established, then the whole cyber infrastructure would be a lawful target.²⁴¹ Governmental and civilian data can be stored in the public cloud, despite the fact that this does not literally satisfy the criteria for segregation. However, the Russia-Ukraine War proved its usefulness in terms of reducing cyber dangers. The Ukrainian government moved an important part of the state’s digital infrastructure to the public cloud in preparation for Russian cyber operations against its governmental data center.²⁴² In this sense, cloud technology turns the disadvantage of cyber infrastructure’s interconnectedness into an advantage. As a more advanced example, the Estonian government established a ‘data embassy’ whose ‘resources are under Estonian state control, secured against cyberattacks or crisis situations with KSI [Keyless Signature Infrastructure] Blockchain technology, and are capable not only providing data backups, but also operating the most critical services’.²⁴³ The particular advantage of such precautions compared with network segregation is that they protect civilian data not only from cyber attacks but also from other types of crises that might occur within states’ borders, such as natural disasters or kinetic attacks.²⁴⁴ If such precautions impose a significant burden on the belligerent and are not feasible solutions, belligerent parties should search for other ways to shield civilian © 2023 The Author Journal compilation © 2023 Edward Elgar Publishing Ltd Downloaded from https://www.elgaronline.com/ at 07/16/2025 08:36:46PM via University College London (UCL)</https:> The Military Law and the Law of War Review, Vol. 61 No. 1 networks against cyber operations.²⁴⁵ The pertinent precaution could be the establishment of ‘digital safe havens’ through agreements between belligerent parties; while some systems may be difficult to negotiate due to their potential assistance to the adversary’s military effort, other systems critical to civilian life may be easily agreed upon.²⁴⁶ ## 4.3 The location of military objectives It is stated in Article 58(b) of the AP-I that belligerent parties should ‘avoid locating military objectives within or near densely populated areas’. From this perspective, parties to the conflict should refrain from locating both movable and immovable objects close to densely populated areas in order to protect civilians under their control.²⁴⁷ Nevertheless, the rule should not be limited to densely populated areas but also include ‘hospitals, cultural property, places of worship, prisoner of war camps, and other facilities which are entitled to specific protection’²⁴⁸ by refraining from locating cyber military objectives in or around them.\nWhile the applicability of the rule is understood in a physical sense, and social media or other similar civilian websites ‘cannot be equated with densely populated areas’, the rule obliges parties to take measures by considering cyber infrastructures which are physically located in the territory of a party.²⁴⁹ Therefore, for instance, army cyber commands should not be located in places where civilians or special protected objects can be put in danger. However, there is a significant hurdle to locating defence ministries in a place which is not close to densely populated areas. On the other hand, it is still possible for parties to exclude these kinds of facilities, which are military in nature but almost impossible to locate in isolated places, from the ambit of the attack through negotiation. Even if they cannot be attacked, it is possible for a party to conduct disruptive cyber operations against cyber infrastructures in these facilities. At this point, cyber operations give a unique opportunity to parties not to harm civilians but to still have an impact on the military capacity of their enemies.\n²⁴⁵. For example, civilians might be supported by providing them with software products such as anti-virus programs that limit the damage from cyber attacks, detecting civilian cyber systems in order to warn people in case of intrusion attempts, providing them technical assistance when their computer systems are harmed, providing a back-up system to store civilian data, blocking particular IP addresses which pose risks to civilian systems, and keeping ready a system that makes it possible to disconnect an entire country from the Internet when all measures are exhausted.²⁵² While the title of Article 58 includes ‘attacks’, paragraph (c) clearly states that some precautions should be applied to operations. Although Jensen admits the ambiguity of this situation, he argues that countries which are not parties to the AP-I have responsibility arising from this provision for those acts that reach ‘attack’ threshold.²⁵³ In the Tallinn Manual, even though the majority of experts stated that the rule is applicable only to cyber attacks because of the title of the article and the non-existence of customary law, the minority focused on the wording of paragraph (c) by accepting cyber operations within the ambit of this rule.²⁵⁴ Therefore, the minority view kept the threshold lower, determined disruptive operations to be covered by this rule, and obligated parties to take precautions against the effects of these operations.²⁵⁵ However, both parties have a common understanding on the non-application of the rule to ‘mere inconvenience or irritation’.²⁵⁶ There is no clear-cut answer on which precautions should be taken within the ambit of Article 58(c), since the provision serves as a gap-filler in the article. Despite the fact that it did not receive much attention in the past because the suitability of other provisions for kinetic activities made them more visible than paragraph (c), their relative unsuitability for cyber operations rendered this clause more important. At this point, the implementation of the norm in cyberspace has already begun to be shaped by the practices of both state and non-state actors, and this trend seems to be continuing and getting better. For example, the US government has begun to warn private entities when they are subjected to transborder cyber attacks and has provided them with cyber tools and training to combat those attacks.²⁵⁷ Furthermore, the Security Service of Ukraine informs civilians about cyber threats and what measures to take in order to avoid them.²⁵⁸ As a recent innovative example, the ICRC has been conducting research on creating a ‘digital emblem’ for the past two years in order to enable the identification of objects, systems, or networks that cannot be subject to cyber attacks.²⁵⁹ Lastly, even though these are individual precautionary measures, the Russia-Ukraine War has also demonstrated how state and non-state entities can collaborate to © 2023 The Author Journal compilation © 2023 Edward Elgar Publishing Ltd Downloaded from https://www.elgaronline.com/ at 07/16/2025 08:36:46PM via University College London (UCL)</https:> The Military Law and the Law of War Review, Vol. 61 No. 1 protect civilians from the effects of cyber operations. The Microsoft Report highlights two examples of cyber security measures against Russian cyber activities: The first has been the use of technology acquired from RiskIQ that identifies and maps organizational attack surfaces, including devices that are unpatched against known vulnerabilities and therefore are the most susceptible to attack. This information has been shared with the Ukrainian government free of charge to enable it to accelerate the strengthening of cyber-defenses. Ukrainian network defenders worked tirelessly with the constant support of the CERT UA within the government to use this information to protect computers across the country.\nThe second measure has been a wartime innovation pursued with the collaboration and support of the Ukrainian government.     "The Military Law and the Law of War Review, Vol. 61 No. 1, 2023, pp. 3–38\n\n# The application of the principle of precautions to cyber operations\n\nYunus Emre Gül*\nFaculty of Law, University of Bonn\n\nThe interconnected nature of cyberspace hardens the application of the principle of precautions to cyber operations. Despite the fact that the principle of precautions falls behind the other two principles that regulate the conduct of hostilities (i.e., the principles of distinction and proportionality), its practical importance renders it as significant as those latter principles. However, in order to truly apply the principle of precautions in this complex environment, it should be applied by tilting it towards humanity rather than seeking to balance humanity with military necessity.\n\nL'interconnexion du cyberespace renforce l'application du principe de précaution aux cyberopérations. Bien que le principe de précaution soit subordonné aux deux autres principes qui régissent la conduite des hostilités (à savoir les principes de distinction et de proportionnalité), son importance pratique le place sur le même plan que ceux-ci. Si on veut toutefois appliquer véritablement le principe de précaution dans cet environnement complexe, celui-ci devrait tendre vers l'humanité plutôt que de chercher à équilibrer l'humanité et les besoins militaires.\n\nDe onderlinge verbondenheid van de cyberruimte versterkt de toepassing van het voorzorgsbeginsel op cyberoperaties. Ondanks het feit dat het voorzorgsbeginsel ondergeschikt is aan de twee andere beginselen die het voeren van vijandelijkheden regelen (namelijk de beginselen van onderscheid en evenredigheid), is het door zijn praktisch belang even belangrijk als deze laatste beginselen. Om het voorzorgsbeginsel in deze complexe omgeving werkelijk toe te passen, moet die toepassing echter eerder overhellen naar de menselijkheid dan een evenwicht te zoeken tussen menselijkheid en militaire noodzaak.\n\nLa naturaleza interconectada del ciberespacio dificulta la aplicación del principio de precaución a las operaciones cibernéticas. A pesar de que el principio de precaución no tiene la misma importancia que los otros dos principios que regulan la conducción de las hostilidades (es decir, los principios de distinción y proporcionalidad), su relevancia práctica le convierte en un principio tan significativo como estos últimos. Sin embargo, para aplicar verdaderamente el principio de precaución en este entorno complejo, esto debe hacerse inclinándolo más hacia lo humanitario en lugar de buscar equilibrar humanidad con necesidad militar.\n\nLa natura interconnessa del cyberspazio rafforza l'applicazione del principio di precauzione nelle operazioni cyber. Nonostante il fatto che il principio di precauzione sia oscurato dai due principi che regolano la condotta delle ostilità (i.e. il principio di proporzionalità e distinzione), la sua importanza pratica lo rende significativo quanto\n\n* This article is an expanded version of the author’s LLM thesis (King’s College London). The shorter version of the thesis has also been published as a book chapter in Turkish. The author can be reached at yunus.gul@uni-bonn.de.\n\n© 2023 The Author\n\nJournal compilation © 2023 Edward Elgar Publishing Ltd\nThe Lypiatts, 15 Lansdown Road, Cheltenham, Glos GL50 2JA, UK\nand The William Pratt House, 9 Dewey Court, Northampton MA 01060-3815, USA\n\nDownloaded from https://www.elgaronline.com/ at 07/16/2025 08:36:46PM\n\nvia University College London (UCL)",
    "4 The Military Law and the Law of War Review, Vol. 61 No. 1\n\nquesti utimi due principi. Tuttavia, al fine di applicare realmente il principio di precauzione a tale complesso scenario, esso dovrebbe essere applicato con un'accezione che miri più all'umanità piuttosto che cercare di bilanciarla con le necessità militari.\n\nDie Vernetzung des Cyberspace verstärkt die Anwendung des Vorsorgeprinzips auf Cyberoperationen. Trotz der Tatsache, dass das Vorsorgeprinzip den beiden anderen Prinzipien zur Regelung von Feindseligkeiten (nämlich den Prinzipien der Unterscheidung und der Verhältnismäßigkeit) untergeordnet ist, ist es wegen seiner praktischen Bedeutung ebenso wichtig wie diese letztgenannten Prinzipien. Um dieses Vorsorgeprinzip in dieser komplexen Umgebung tatsächlich anzuwenden, hat diese Anwendung vielmehr die Menschlichkeit als ein Gleichgewicht zwischen Menschlichkeit und militärischer Notwendigkeit anzustreben.\n\nKeywords: cyberspace, interconnectedness, precautions, humanity, cyber operations\n\n# 1 INTRODUCTION\n\nThere are three principles that govern the conduct of hostilities: the principles of distinction, proportionality and precautions. However, despite its practical importance, the principle of precautions seems to trail behind the other two concepts.¹ This negligence extends not only to scholarly works but also to military doctrines. While the first two principles are often referred to as ‘principles’ in military manuals, the third does not have such a privilege.² Nonetheless, it not only confirms or supplements these former principles but also prescribes some preliminary measures to avoid violating them.³\n\nOn the other hand, the Law of Armed Conflict (LOAC) rules, which regulate the application of the principle of precautions, were designed to be applied during conventional warfare. Due to the interconnected nature of the cyber domain, however, it is difficult to apply these rules to cyber operations. Before discussing the complexity posed by the interconnectivity of cyberspace, it should be admitted that it is not unique to the cyber domain; traditional domains have this problem too. Almost half a century ago, the reality that there is ‘a geographical and functional mixture of combatants and civilians and military objectives and civilian objects’ in the conduct of military air\n\n1.     "The application of the principle of precautions to cyber operations 5\n\noperations was discussed, and the importance of taking precautionary measures was emphasized in a pamphlet published by the United States (US) Air Force.⁴ Despite the similarity between the traditional and cyber domains in terms of interconnectivity, what makes interconnectivity special regarding cyber military operations is that it ‘characterises cyberspace, which means that whatever has an interface with the Internet can be affected by cyber operations conducted from anywhere in the world’.⁵ In such a complex environment, the adoption of the principle of precautions while planning and executing cyber operations has utmost importance.\n\nThe interconnectivity problem should be approached from two perspectives, taking into account both the technical and the social factors. From the first standpoint, technical factors intensify the interconnectedness between military and civilian networks in cyberspace, therefore converting this domain into one of entirely dual-use nature and obstructing the distinction between military targets and civilian objects. As Jensen points out, ‘[w]ith 98% of day-to-day government communications routinely travelling over civilian communication lines, there will be many civilian lines of communication that will carry targetable electronic traffic intermixed with civilian traffic’.⁶ From this vantage point, not only is it highly difficult to make a certain distinction between civilian and military cyber infrastructures, but practically all military cyber activities must be carried out through dual-use cyber systems.⁷ In the absence of precautionary measures against such interconnectivity, the impacts of cyber activities might quickly spread to other systems across the globe and have the potential to significantly disrupt daily civilian life by having adverse impacts on civilian critical infrastructure and other associated systems.⁸ From this point of view, a cyber operation designed to disrupt a dual-used power plant located in a belligerent state could easily impair other systems, from water and food to ICT infrastructure, and its unintended effects might spill over into neutral countries.⁹\n\nFrom the second point of view, interconnection becomes a more complicated matter when social factors are considered. Even though they are less obvious than technical ones, they still pose threats comparable to those of the latter, and it necessitates especially defensive parties to take unique precautionary measures. When this fact about a single facility is considered along with the global challenge of interconnectivity, the magnitude of the interconnectivity issue could be better understood.\n\nGiven that measures to prevent adversarial effects on cyber systems cannot keep up with their level of interconnectivity,¹¹ this article aims to portray how to apply the principle of precautions to cyber operations and answers this question by taking its humanity-based character into account. The present author acknowledges that the articles articulating the principle of precautions are vague, as stated by state delegates during the negotiations of Additional Protocol-I or by state legal advisers.¹² Such views on specific provisions of the article or the article as a whole are expressed using terms like ‘open to a variety of interpretations by the conflicting parties’¹³ (for Article 57(2)(a)(ii)), ‘subjective’¹⁴ ‘ambiguous’¹⁵ (for Article 57(2)(a)), ‘deficient in clarity due to its generally vague wording’¹⁶ (for Article 57), and ‘too general’¹⁷ (for articles between 48 and 58).     "The application of the principle of precautions to cyber operations 7\n\nother hand, it should be minimized as much as possible. In other words, ‘[t]he thrust is not absolute elimination of the calamities of war (a goal which would manifestly be utopian), but relief from the tribulations of war “as much as possible” bearing in mind that war is fought to be won’.²² At this point, it sounds rational that these two notions should be balanced while applying the principles governing the conduct of hostilities.\n\nOn the other hand, considering the peculiarity of interconnectedness in cyberspace, this balance should be leaned toward humanity while applying the principle of precautions. There are some reasons in favour of such an interpretation. To begin with, the notion of ‘balance’ is significantly subjective.²³ From a practitioner perspective, when the armed conflict starts, reality does not permit such a compromise,²⁴ and the perception of ‘balance’ is determined by those on the battlefield. However, outside of the conflict, such a balance could be perceived differently by scholars or judges who need to evaluate the legality of such actions, and their views seem more ‘humanitarian’ to practitioners. As stated by Luban, ‘[f]or military lawyers, the starting point is military necessity, and the reigning assumption is that legal regulation of war must accommodate military necessity. For humanitarian lawyers, the starting point is human dignity and human rights’.²⁵ As a result, such disparities in viewpoints considerably alter the perception of balance, and trying to achieve a balance in the principle of precautions seems to be a rhetorical word.\n\nApart from the subjectivity of balance depending on different perceptors, the nature of the LOAC principles inherently provides a lean toward either military necessity or humanity.²⁶ While the principles of distinction and proportionality are more eligible to\n\nmore generally’.     "The Military Law and the Law of War Review, Vol. 61 No. 1\n\nbe interpreted from a military necessity perspective, the principle of precautions goes in the opposite direction. The crux of the former principles is based on gaining military advantage on the battlefield,²⁷ and the notion of military advantage ‘has a particular resonance with “military necessity”’.²⁸ This naturally bends those principles’ interpretation in the direction of military necessity.²⁹ On the other hand, the central tenet of the principle of precautions is based on the minimization of civilian harm. It obliges belligerent parties to take active or passive precautionary measures to mitigate risks, which derive from military operations, towards civilians and civilian property in armed conflicts.³⁰ In line with this, it is not good enough for soldiers ‘merely not intending civilian harm’, but they also ‘must intend not to harm civilians’.³¹\n\nGiven that the nature of the principles requires that they be construed by leaning towards one side, analyzing the principle of precautions by considering the balance poses a risk that it turns into an ‘illusory rule’. According to Schwarzenberger:\n\n[Illusory rules]... are merely a formal compromise between the standard of civilization and the necessities of war. Here, in fact the rule of force is supreme. Rules which expressly proclaim the necessities of war as an overriding constituent element or are emasculated by an ‘as far as possible’ clause illustrate this perhaps slightly hypocritical variant of the rules of warfare.³²\n\nThus, by turning the principle into an ‘illusory rule’, it would be very easy for belligerent parties to refrain from effectively applying the principle of precautions by putting terms such as ‘feasible’ or ‘unless circumstances do not permit’ on the table.³³ To preclude such excuses, one should hold it as a rule that ‘sets limitations to warfare in cases in which considerations of civilization demand priority over military interest’.³⁴ As correctly held by the Madagascar delegate, ‘[t]he article reflected a laudable desire to narrow the gap between the ideal and the possible, and to deal from a humanitarian standpoint with two opposite positions, namely, the aggressor’s and the victim’s’.³⁵ Per this point of view, the application of the principle of precautions by taking ‘one small step’ toward humanity could be ‘one giant leap’ toward a more appropriate\n\n²⁷. See Articles 52(2) and 51(5)(b).\n²⁸. K Watkin, ‘Military Advantage: A Matter of “Value”, Strategy, and Tactics’ (2016) 17 Yearbook of International Humanitarian Law 277.\n²⁹. When the inherent bending of these principles toward military necessity and only their recognition as ‘principles’ in military manuals are considered, the consequence is admitted by Maurer that ‘[i]n more than one context, the balance between military “necessity” and protection concerns has heavily tilted towards military logics, and norms have been implicitly downgraded to mere discretionary guidance’. See B Demeyere, ‘Interview with Peter Maurer: President of the International Committee of the Red Cross (2012–2022)’ (2022) 104 International Review of the Red Cross 1516.\n³⁰. Corn and Schoettler Jr (fn 3) 787.\n³¹. D Luban, ‘Risk Taking and Force Protection’ in Y Benbaji and N Sussman (eds), Reading Walzer (Routledge, 2014) 277.\n³². Therefore, Carnahan views the rules between 48 and 58 as illusory rules, and he exemplifies this by considering those terms in the article articulating the principle of precautions. See ibid.\n³⁴. Official Records-VI 212.\n\n© 2023 The Author\n\nJournal compilation © 2023 Edward Elgar Publishing Ltd\n\nDownloaded from https://www.elgaronline.com/ at 07/16/2025 08:36:46PM\n\nvia University College London (UCL)",
    "The application of the principle of precautions to cyber operations 9\n\nsolution for cyberspace interconnectivity, and it would establish a proper balance between necessity and humanity for the LOAC overall.³⁶\n\nBy keeping in mind this humanity-based character of the principle of precautions, the article aims to examine the application of the principle of precautions to cyber operations in a further three sections, which are organized as follows: In section 2, the background of the article and some debatable terms such as ‘constant care’ and ‘feasibility’ in cyber operations, as well as the responsibility deriving from the principle of precautions will be clarified. In section 3, the precautions that shall be taken by the attacking side of the conflict according to Article 57 of Additional Protocol-I will be examined. In the first part of the section, target verification in cyber operations will be discussed, and some important questions will be answered, e.g., does technical superiority play any role on the precautionary level? Or what is the requisite level of certainty? In the second part, the choice of cyber means and methods will be addressed. The proportionality rule in precautions in planning and executing cyber attacks will be determined in the third part. Not only will key terms such as ‘military advantage’ and ‘incidental harm’ be discussed in that section, but also some grey areas, e.g., the consideration of indirect effects. The fourth part will explain effective warning before launching cyber attacks, and the final part will explain the least-danger rule. In the fourth section, precautions that shall be taken by a party that is subject to cyber operations will be addressed. In this chapter, the segregation of civilian and military objectives in cyberspace, the location of cyber military objectives, and other measures will be questioned, respectively.\n\n## 2 THE REGULATION OF THE PRINCIPLE OF PRECAUTIONS, BASIC TERMS AND RESPONSIBILITY\n\n### 2.1 The regulation of the principle of precautions\n\nWhile it is not stated conspicuously, the first implication of the principle of precautions can be found in Article 27 of the Hague Convention IV, in which it is stated that:\n\nIn sieges and bombardments all necessary steps must be taken to spare, as far as possible, buildings dedicated to religion, art, science, or charitable purposes, historic monuments, hospitals, and places where the sick and wounded are collected, provided they are not being used at the time for military purposes.³⁷\n\nIn the following process, the prohibition to launch an attack against civilians and to spare them as much as possible found a place in various official documents.³⁸ However, the first binding regulation of the principle of precautions appeared in the AP-I,\n\n³⁶. ‘The principles of distinction, precautions and proportionality thus complement each other in a way that achieves a subtle balance between military necessity and humanitarian imperatives.’ See Sari and Tinkler (fn 21) 4.\n\n³⁷. International Conferences (The Hague), Hague Convention (IV) Respecting the Laws and Customs of War on Land and Its Annex: Regulations Concerning the Laws and Customs of War on Land, 18 October 1907.\n\n³⁸. See League of Nations Res ‘Protection of Civilian Populations Against Bombing from the Air in Case of War’ (30 September 1938). Later, more detailed rules were articulated in Articles 8, 9 and 11 of the Draft Rules for the Limitation of the Dangers incurred by the Civilian Population in Time of War (1956). Despite the fact that states did not adopt these rules, they had an impact on the rules codified in Additional Protocols. See S Watts, ‘Law-of-War Precautions: A Cautionary Note’ in RTP Alcala and E Talbot Jensen (eds), The Impact of Emerging Technologies on the Law of Armed Conflict (Oxford University Press, 2019) 116.\n\n© 2023 The Author\n\nJournal compilation © 2023 Edward Elgar Publishing Ltd\n\nDownloaded from https://www.elgaronline.com/ at 07/16/2025 08:36:46PM via University College London (UCL)",
    "The Military Law and the Law of War Review, Vol. 61 No. 1\n\nin which it is stated that both attacking and defending parties shall take precautions to spare civilians and civilian objects in an armed conflict. At this point, for *jus in bello* cyberspace operations, the principle of precautions provides a twofold protection: the first comprises taking constant care while conducting cyber attacks ('precautions in attack'), and the second comprises taking feasible precautions in order to protect civilians from the effects of cyber attacks ('precautions against the effects of attacks') during armed conflicts. These precautions can also be named 'active' and 'passive' precautions ruled under Articles 57 and 58 of the AP-I.\n\nThe rules stated in Articles 57 and 58 are applied in times of armed conflicts, though the definition of 'armed conflict' is not provided in the Protocol. In this article, the definition given in the Tadic Decision, in which it was described as 'a resort to armed force between States or protracted armed violence between governmental authorities and organized armed groups or between such groups within a State',[39] is adopted. From this definition, it can be stated that there are two types of armed conflicts; 'between States' (international armed conflicts), and 'between governmental authorities and organized armed groups or between such groups' (non-international armed conflicts). In identifying the nature of the conflict, the status of the actors is the decisive factor.[40] The importance of this distinction is that while the AP-I, which is applicable to international armed conflicts, clearly states the obligation to take precautions, there is no clear provision which regulates the principle of precautions in Additional Protocol-II,[41] which is applicable to non-international armed conflicts. However, it does not prevent the application of the principle to the latter type of conflicts since it is stated in Article 13(1) of the AP-II that '[t]he civilian population and individual civilians shall enjoy general protection against the dangers arising from military operations'. Therefore, it is argued in the work of the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) on Customary Rules that, by approving the customary nature of the principle for both international and non-international armed conflict, it is hard to abide by such a rule without taking any precaution.[42] Moreover, it is stated in the Tadic Decision that 'all necessary precautions should be taken to avoid injury, loss or damage to civilian populations' in all kinds of armed conflicts by referring to a resolution adopted by the United Nations General Assembly.[43] Finally, two recent treaties that are applicable to non-international armed conflicts explicitly regulate the principle of precautions.[44]\n\n39. J-M Henckaerts and L Doswald-Beck (eds), *Customary International Humanitarian Law* (Cambridge University Press, 2005) 52. This is also approved in military manuals of various countries such as Benin, Germany and Nigeria. See ibid at 53, supra note 11.\n43. Tadic Decision, paras 111-12. The customary nature of the principle of precautions is also recognized by other international court decisions. See Prosecutor v. Zoran Kuprešić and others (Judgement) ICTY-95-16-T (14 January 2000) paras 524-26; Juan Carlos Abella. V. Argentina IACiHR Case No. 11.137 (18 November 1997) paras 177-78.\n44. Protocol on Prohibitions or Restrictions on the Use of Mines, Booby-Traps and Other Devices (Protocol II) (As Amended on 3 May 1996) ('Mine Protocol') 10 October 1980, Article 3(10); Second Protocol to the Hague Convention of 1954 for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict (26 March 1999) Article 7.\n\n© 2023 The Author\n\nJournal compilation © 2023 Edward Elgar Publishing Ltd\n\nDownloaded from https://www.elgaronline.com/ at 07/16/2025 08:36:46PM via University College London (UCL)",
    "The application of the principle of precautions to cyber operations 11\n\nIt is crucial to make the distinction between military operations and attacks since some precautions are applicable to all military operations, as stated in Article 57 (1) and (4), though others can only be applied to attacks.⁴⁵ However, when these provisions are read together with Article 49, it might cause confusion in the first instance because while Article 49(3) clearly restricts the application of Section IV rules of the AP-I to operations conducted in the air or sea which have impacts on ‘civilians or civilian objects on land’, Article 57(4) seems to obligate parties to respect the principle of precautions in the conduct of these operations without any limitation. To solve this problem, one should deem Article 57(4) as ‘merely a restatement of one of the existing rules’.⁴⁶ As Article 49(3) makes clear, the article does not affect those rules that are customary in nature and applicable to all types of military operations. Therefore, Article 57(4) does not contradict but rather ‘complement’ it.⁴⁷\n\nSince the principle of precautions applies to both operations and attacks, both of these terms should be clarified. At this point, military operations are ‘any movements, manoeuvres and other activities whatsoever carried out by the armed forces with a view to combat’.⁴⁸ Therefore, all parties to the conflict should exercise constant care while conducting their military operations. For instance, if a tank driver harms civilian property while maneuvering the vehicle, he/she will be responsible due to the breach of the principle of precautions.⁴⁹ From this perspective, if a perpetrator destroys a civilian network while conducting cyber exploitation against either a civilian or military cyber system, he/she will bear responsibility. However, military attacks require a certain threshold since they are violent acts causing death, injury, damage, or destruction – or at least intending to do so.⁵⁰ As a result, all military attacks are kinds of military operations but vice versa would not be true. Therefore, while cyber operation can be defined as ‘the employment of cyber capabilities to achieve objectives in or through cyberspace’,⁵¹ cyber attack is ‘a cyber operation, whether offensive or defensive, that is reasonably expected to cause injury or death to persons or damage or destruction to objects’.⁵² In light of this, cyber attack is a special kind of cyber operation that results in violent effects. However, cyber attacks require a broader understanding because damage to objects may occur as a secondary effect of cyber operations. Therefore, the present author agrees with the approach of the majority of the International Group of Experts (the Experts), who prepared the Tallinn Manual, that cyber operations that result in the replacement of a component by having an impact on the functionality of an object fall within the ambit of attack because, while these kinds of operations do not damage an object in the first instance, their effects in later phases reach the threshold of attack by causing physical harm.⁵³\n\n⁴⁵. W Heintschel von Heinegg, ‘Precautions in Attack’ in Max Planck Encyclopaedia of Public International Law (2015) para 5.\n⁴⁶. Carnahan (fn 33) 60.\n⁴⁷. Ibid.\n⁴⁸. Sandoz, Swinarski and Zimmermann (eds) (fn 3) para 2191.\n⁴⁹. APV Rogers, Law on the Battlefield (Manchester University Press, 1996) 57.\n⁵⁰. Tallinn Manual, Rule 92.\n⁵¹. Ibid at Glossary.\n⁵². Ibid at Rule 92.\n⁵³. Ibid at Rule 92 Cmt. para 10; Gisel and Olejnik (fn 11) 38. Although there is a discussion about whether cyber operations that cause the reinstallation of the operating system or the loss of usability of cyber infrastructure can be accepted as an ‘attack’, the present author considers that these positions do not reflect lex lata. See Tallinn Manual Rule 92 Cmt. paras 11–12; Gisel and Olejnik (fn 11) 38.\n\n© 2023 The Author\n\nJournal compilation © 2023 Edward Elgar Publishing Ltd\n\nDownloaded from https://www.elgaronline.com/ at 07/16/2025 08:36:46PM\n\nvia University College London (UCL)",
    "The Military Law and the Law of War Review, Vol. 61 No. 1\n\nTo sum up, there is no rule which prohibits developing and using cyber capabilities, but ‘states are obliged to ensure their use of cyber capabilities accords with international law and norms of acceptable behaviour’⁵⁴ including relevant rules of the LOAC. At this point, the applicability of international law to cyber operations is recognized by states and international organizations.⁵⁵ Also, there is a certain difference between a cyber operation and an attack, and not all precautionary measures are applicable to all kinds of cyber operations.\n\n## 2.2 Constant care\n\nAccording to Article 57(1) of the AP-I, the attacking party shall always take ‘constant care’ to spare civilians and civilian objects while conducting military operations. The term ‘constant care’ is clarified in the HPCR Manual Commentary by stating that ‘there are no exceptions from the duty to seek to spare the civilian population, civilians and civilian objects’.⁵⁶ Therefore, constant care obliges all levels of the armed forces who are responsible for planning, ordering or executing a cyber operation to always consider the results of it and try to minimize its effects on civilians.⁵⁷\n\nThe ‘constant care’ obligation is necessary for cyber operations. Those who are involved in the operation should always be aware of the foreseeable effects of operations on the civilian population and property and try to minimize these effects as much as possible. For this reason, it is not enough to demonstrate due care in the planning stage; this obligation extends to all stages of the operation in which civilians might be affected. In other words, these people should have ‘situational awareness at all times’.⁵⁸ The concept of situational awareness is explained in the Allied Joint Doctrine for Cyberspace Operations by describing it as ‘a combination of a near real-time updated RCP [Recognised Cyberspace Picture], analysis and information management’.⁵⁹ Although the obligation is constrained by the execution stage of an operation as described in the article, the effects of the attack can continue. For example, in the\n\n⁵⁴. Commonwealth of Australia, *Australia’s International Cyber Engagement Strategy* (2017) 45.\n⁵⁵. For some state commitments, see ibid; J Wright, ‘Cyber and International Law in the 21st Century’ (23 May 2018), available at <https: government=\"\" cyber-and-international-law-in-the-21st-century=\"\" speech=\"\" speech(cyber-and-international-law-in-the-21st-century)=\"\" www.gov.uk=\"\"> (accessed 30 March 2023); H Hongju Koh, ‘International Law in Cyberspace’ (*U.S. Department of State*, 18 September 2012), available at <https: 197924.htm=\"\" 2009-2017.state.gov=\"\" l=\"\" releases=\"\" remarks=\"\" r924=\"\"> (accessed 30 March 2023). With respect to documents prepared by international organizations, see UNGGE Report 2013 (A/68/98) and 2015 (A/70/174). However, it should be admitted that the negotiation process was harmed significantly in 2017. See M Schmitt and L Vihul, ‘International Cyber Law Politicized: The UN GGE’s Failure to Advance Cyber Norms’ (*Just Security*, 30 June 2017), available at <https: 42768=\"\" international-cyber-law-politicized-gges-failure-advance-cybernorms=\"\" www.justsecurity.org=\"\"></https:> (accessed 30 March 2023).\n⁵⁶. *Commentary on the HPCR Manual on International Law Applicable to Air and Missile Warfare* (Program on Humanitarian Policy and Conflict Research at Harvard University 2010) 125 (‘HPCR Manual Commentary’).\n⁵⁷. UK Ministry of Defence (fn 2) para 5.32.1. The US position seems more cautious about accepting the obligation. See US Department of Defence (fn 2) para 5.2.3.5.\n⁵⁸.     "The application of the principle of precautions to cyber operations 13\n\nStuxnet case, even though the malware was exclusively designed to target SCADA (Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition) systems of the Iranian nuclear facility and the production of energy was reduced significantly, the malware spread around the world without the intention of its creators.⁶⁰ Although Jensen notes that this ‘at least implicates the constant-care standard and informs State practice on the issue’,⁶¹ the present author considers that the possible effects of the cyber operations after their execution are better understood 10 years later, so states should seek to stop or at least limit the effects of operations after their military objective is accomplished.\n\nOn the other hand, the application of the rule in cyberspace poses a significant hurdle since almost all cyber operations might affect or harm civilian cyber infrastructure to some extent.⁶² However, after all feasible precautions have been taken by an attacker, the relevant rule will be proportionality. If the effects of the operation on civilians are not excessive compared to the anticipated military advantage, then the attacking party may continue to carry out cyber operations. However, the calculation may be difficult because of the time-sensitivity. Planned operations give more chance to the attacking party to take better precautions, though time-sensitive ones generally do not permit sufficient time to implement more suitable precautions.⁶³ Although the impact of such a condition on precautions is not deniable, it does not give permission to the attacker to deviate from the principle because the constant care obligation necessitates parties to take feasible precautions in all circumstances.⁶⁴\n\nThe second significant hurdle might be the secretive nature of cyberspace since ambiguity is at the centre of cyber warfare.⁶⁵ Even though attribution may be difficult in that domain and the perpetrator of cyber acts that violate the LOAC cannot be easily found, parties to the conflict should obey the rules of the LOAC by considering warrior ethics. From this perspective, cyber warriors should always seek ways to mitigate risks towards civilians in good faith since ‘[r]espect for LOAC obligations is the essential touchstone for that ethical foundation’.⁶⁶ This ethical foundation serves for better protection of civilians, which is an inherent objective of the LOAC.⁶⁷\n\nLast but not least, the ‘constant care’ obligation should not be accepted as limited to this article. It involves all phases of operations and attacks, which are carried out by both attacking and defending parties. For this reason, it has a guidance function while examining all provisions of Articles 57 and 58.\n\n## 2.3 Feasibility\n\nArticle 57 obliges parties to take ‘feasible’ precautions in order to minimize the effects of an attack on civilians and civilian objects. In the Official Commentary of Article 57, it is stated that those precautions are ‘everything that was practicable or practically possible, taking into account all the circumstances at the time of the attack, including\n\n⁶⁰.     "The Military Law and the Law of War Review, Vol. 61 No. 1\n\nthose relevant to the success of military operations'.68 The second part of the definition has been modified in the Mine Protocol by not constraining it with military success but adding the phrase 'including humanitarian and military considerations'69 when defining the term 'feasible'.\n\nParties to the conflict do not need to take 'perfect' precautions; it is enough to take precautions that are practically possible under circumstances ruling at the time.70 That is why feasibility should be determined on a contextual basis. At this point, every situation has its unique features, and those responsible for an attack should adapt various precautions by considering the characteristics of the situation. For example, an attacker party should map the target network through exploitation operations if it is connected to other civilian networks.71 In such situations, LOAC not only permits cyber espionage but also obligates a belligerent party to conduct these operations. However, such operations require a certain level of technical expertise, and in the absence of that, such a network should not be exploited.72 Despite such expertise, some mistakes may occur in the 'fog of war'.73 At this point, a commander who took 'all due measures' is not responsible for this harm.74 Those measures can be identified by different factors such as available cyber means, time sensitivity, the cyber defence system of the enemy, the characteristics of the target, intelligence assets, the expertise of the attacking team, the loyalty of the enemy of to the LOAC, and available assets and vulnerabilities of the enemy.75 However, even if feasible precautions are taken, unintended results may occur for various reasons, such as failure of the intelligence system, dysfunction of the technology, or unexpected changes in tactical conditions.76 For instance, a commander might prepare a map of a cyber network before conducting an attack, but the virus unintentionally spreads among the civilian infrastructure, which has a connection with the military network.77 At this point, while deciding on whether the principle of precautions is respected or not, one should not focus on outcomes, but compliance should be measured by the process in which an\n\n68.     "The application of the principle of precautions to cyber operations 15\n\nattacking party makes diligent efforts.⁷⁸ For instance, if an attacker has advanced cyber capabilities that make it possible to disrupt an electrical grid without harming civilians but prefers to carry out an attack by conventional means – which results in civilian damage – it cannot claim that its adversary does not use the same level of technology to refrain from harming civilians.⁷⁹ Thus, it is true that each party has a responsibility ‘within its means or methods or its capability’ as stated by the Indian delegate.⁸⁰\n\nEven if the commander has advanced cyber weapons, he/she may try to spare them for use during later stages of the conflict by taking military considerations into account. Therefore, it is permitted for the military commander in the Naval Manual of Ecuador to use alternative methods ‘in light of all the facts known or reasonably available to him, including the need to conserve resources and complete the mission successfully’.⁸¹ However, if it is understood that using less advanced weapons will result in excessive collateral damage, then they should either use advanced ones or cancel the attack.⁸²\n\nOn the other hand, the determination of feasibility on a contextual basis should not be used to assuage the burden from the shoulders of the attacker. For example, the use of white phosphorus shells near al-Wafa hospital, where patients have serious injuries and need long-term care, by the Israeli armed forces was deemed a violation of Articles 57(2)(b) and (c) of the AP-I.⁸³ It was stated that those who were responsible for the attack should be aware of ‘all the facts and circumstances’.⁸⁴ For this reason, while conducting a cyber operation against a system in which some medical records may be located, the attacking party should take special care. The same is valid for facilities such as dams, where dangerous forces are located.⁸⁵\n\n## 2.4 Responsibility\n\nThe wording of Article 57 restricts its applicability to ‘those who plan or decide upon an attack’. Because of this wording, some states have expressed reservations about Article 57, claiming that it only applies to ‘commanding officers at the battalion or group level and those of higher ranks’.⁸⁶ Nonetheless, every soldier who breaches obligations imposed by the LOAC bears individual criminal responsibility for his/her acts when such crimes are committed with ‘intent and knowledge’.⁸⁷ At this point, it does\n\n⁷⁸. Ibid at 2.\n⁸⁰. Official Records-VI 228.\n⁸¹. Henckaerts and Doswald-Beck (fn 68) 376–77, para 278.\n⁸². K Watkin, ‘Targeting in Air Warfare’ (2014) 44 Israel Yearbook on Human Rights 1, 57.\n⁸³. Report of the United Nations Fact-Finding Mission on the Gaza Conflict, UN Doc A/HRC/ 12/48 (25 September 2009) paras 630–52 (‘Goldstone Report’).\n⁸⁴. Ibid at para 648.\n⁸⁵. Article 56 of the AP-I; HPCR Manual Commentary 131.\n⁸⁶. Declaration made by Switzerland in Henckaerts and Doswald-Beck (fn 68) 358, para 156. Some authors call this an ‘arbitrary determination’ since ‘it is not clear why echelons below a battalion are not capable of complying with this rule’. See JJ Merriam, ‘Affirmative Target Identification: Operationalizing the Principle of Distinction for US Warfighters’ (2016) 56 Virginia Journal of International Law 83, 103.\n⁸⁷.     "The Military Law and the Law of War Review, Vol. 61 No. 1\n\nnot seem appropriate to constrain it with higher levels of command since junior levels of command may fall into a time-sensitive position in which they must make important decisions without prior advice from their superiors.⁸⁸ Also, it might be possible to operate in smaller groups in different types of warfare, such as national liberation wars or transnational armed conflicts.⁸⁹ In line with this, the rule should be applied at ‘whatever level the regulated functions are being performed’⁹⁰ since every soldier who conducts military operations against an adversary by aiming to obtain military advantage participates in the decision-making process in the theatre of war.⁹¹ As a result, individuals ‘who have the authority and practical possibility to affect the course of an attack’ should be held accountable for cyber activities.⁹²\n\nIn cyberspace, it may be very hard to calculate the effects of an attack by planners or decision makers since the interconnectedness of civilian and military networks prevents the attacking party from properly calculating the effects of an attack and from taking feasible precautions in order to minimize them.⁹³ Also, the velocity of computer systems operating at high speed makes it difficult to predict the indirect effects of cyber attacks.⁹⁴ As it is stated in the ICRC Expert Meeting:\n\nOwing to how the internet is designed and operates, there will always be the risk of other systems or networks being affected. The reason is that volumetric attacks can end up using all available channel capacity, which would affect the networks on the path to the target. This has happened in the past, with powerful DDoS attacks launched against specific targets and affecting entire internet infrastructure providers.⁹⁵\n\nHowever, the unpredictability of effects does not relieve the responsibility of all levels of command while conducting operations. According to Watkin, operational factors cannot be put forward in order not to take feasible precautions in today’s trend, which pursues to compromise ‘human rights-like accountability frameworks with operational decision making during armed conflict’.⁹⁶ Accordingly, all members of the armed forces who are part of operations in cyberspace should do everything feasible within their limits.\n\nWhile assessing the individual responsibility of officers, they should be judged by how much they know about a certain subject. The well-known example is the Rendulic Decision, in which the Nuremberg Tribunal held that ‘the “scorched earth” policy in\n\n⁸⁸ Sandoz, Swinarski and Zimmermann (eds) (fn 3) 2197; APV Rogers, ‘General Report-Conduct of Combat and Risks Run by the Civilian Population’ (1982) 21 Mil. See also International Committee of the Red Cross, Draft Additional Protocols to the Geneva Conventions of August 12, 1949 (1973) 64.\n⁹³ E Boylan, ‘Applying the Law of Proportionality to Cyber Conflict: Suggestions for Practitioners’ (2017) 50 Vanderbilt Journal of Transnational Law 235.\n⁹⁴ Ibid at 236.\n⁹⁵ Gisel and Olejnik (fn 11) 30.\n⁹⁶ Watkin (fn 82) 56.\n\n© 2023 The Author\n\nJournal compilation © 2023 Edward Elgar Publishing Ltd\n\nDownloaded from https://www.elgaronline.com/ at 07/16/2025 08:36:46PM\n\nvia University College London (UCL)",
    "The application of the principle of precautions to cyber operations 17\n\nFinmark as a precautionary measure against an attack$^{97}$ could not be accepted as a violation of the LOAC because the relevant evidence at the time supported such a measurement by the commander. For this reason, later evidence which showed that ‘the danger did not actually exist’$^{98}$ cannot be used to convict the commander since he ‘acted within the limits of honest judgment on the basis of the conditions prevailing at the time’.$^{99}$ This is crucial considering the interconnectivity of cyberspace since cyber attacks might affect civilian networks unexpectedly despite a commander’s employment of the advanced technology to conduct constant surveillance over a network.$^{100}$ At this point, the responsibility arising out of a cyber attack would not go beyond what the defendant knew at the time of the attack.\n\nOn the other hand, one needs to distinguish misinformation from misconception. Misconception of the nature of the target might occur because of cognitive bias, which misdirects attackers by analyzing information ‘in a manner that supports their pre-existing beliefs or mental frameworks’.$^{101}$ States should employ a variety of techniques such as ‘training and education, red teaming procedures, specific positive identification (PID) policies for targeting, use of structured analytic techniques, and other analytic tradecraft practices’ in order for this not to result in civilian damage.$^{102}$ Despite the fact that states are keen to protect soldiers in such situations,$^{103}$ inflicting civilian harm due to biased decisions does not very well fit with the notion of ‘honest judgement’.\n\nLastly, those who undertake cyber operations may be fully aware of the results of their actions owing to their technical expertise since cyberspace requires unique understanding compared to traditional domains. If a higher commander issues an order to launch a cyber operation without being aware of the outcomes in good faith, inferior commanders will be responsible for such intentional conduct. However, if a commander is aware that he lacks sufficient information about a target, he should either change the concept of the attack or refrain from issuing such an order.$^{104}$ Should an operation continue to be carried out while being aware of this insufficiency, responsibility arises.\n\n# 3 PRECAUTIONS IN ATTACK\n\n## 3.1 Target verification\n\nIt is stated in Article 57(2) of the AP-I that:\n\n(a) those who plan or decide upon an attack shall:\n(i) do everything feasible to verify that the objectives to be attacked are neither civilians nor civilian objects and are not subject to special protection but are military objectives within the\n\n97.     "The Military Law and the Law of War Review, Vol. 61 No. 1\n\nmeaning of paragraph 2 of Article 52 and that it is not prohibited by the provisions of this Protocol to attack them.\n\nThe rationale behind this provision is to prevent carrying out attacks against objectives that are not military in nature because of misinformation or against military objectives in order to get a small military advantage by significantly harming civilians and objects.^[105]^\n\nThe binding definition of military objectives is codified in Article 52(2) of the AP-I, which states that:\n\n[M]ilitary objectives are limited to those objects which by their nature, location, purpose or use make an effective contribution to military action and whose total or partial destruction, capture or neutralization, in the circumstances ruling at the time, offers a definite military advantage.\n\nFrom this definition, there must be two cumulative elements ('two-pronged test')^[106]^ in order to deem an object as military, which are effective contribution and military advantage. For this reason, an object that is military in nature should not be subject to attack if it does not effectively contribute to the military capacity of an enemy.^[107]^\n\nWhile only Article 52(2) of the AP-I has found its place in the provision, lawful targets also include people who can be made the object of direct cyber attacks. According to the LOAC, various categories of people can be held as lawful targets. The first one consists of combatants who are members of the armed forces and have a right to directly participate in hostilities.^[108]^ Even though they are lawful targets, they have a right to be treated as prisoners of war when they are captured by the enemy.^[109]^\n\nThe second category includes direct participants in hostilities. Although they are civilian in nature, they will be accepted as lawful targets if they meet three cumulative criteria which are: threshold of harm, direct causation and belligerent nexus.^[110]^ Those people are lawful targets 'for such time as they take a direct part in hostilities',^[111]^ and if they are captured, they cannot benefit from prisoner of war status.\n\nThe third category, though there is a discussion on it, consists of members of an organized armed group that is a belligerent party in an armed conflict. They are 'individuals whose continuous function involves the preparation, execution, or command of acts or operations amounting to direct participation in hostilities'.^[112]^\n\n105. Sandoz, Swinarski and Zimmermann (eds) (fn 3) para 2193.\n106. Bothe, Partsch and Solf (fn 89) 365; HB Robertson, 'The Principle of the Military Objective in the Law of Armed Conflict' (1997) 8 United States Air Force Academy Journal of Legal Studies 35, 40, 48.\n107. Henderson (fn 92) 50.\n108. AP-I Article 43(2).\n109. AP-I Article 44(1).\n110. In the Interpretive Guidance on the Notion of Direct Participation in Hostilities, definitions of these criteria read as follows: '1. the act must be likely to adversely affect the military operations or military capacity of a party to an armed conflict or, alternatively, to inflict death, injury, or destruction on persons or objects protected against direct attack (threshold of harm), and 2. there must be a direct causal link between the act and the harm likely to result either from that act, or from a coordinated military operation of which that act constitutes an integral part (direct causation), and 3. the act must be specifically designed to directly cause the required threshold of harm in support of a party to the conflict and to the detriment of another (belligerent nexus).' See N Melzer, Interpretive Guidance on the Notion of Direct Participation in Hostilities under International Humanitarian Law (International Committee of the Red Cross 2009) 46.\n111.     "The application of the principle of precautions to cyber operations 19\n\nAt first glance, the second and third categories may seem identical, but the difference is that while civilians who fall into the former categories ‘directly participate in hostilities on a merely spontaneous, sporadic, or unorganized basis’, the latter category of people has a continuous combat function, which ‘requires lasting integration into an organised armed group acting as the armed forces of a non-state party to an armed conflict’.¹¹³ The result of this distinction is that those who directly participate in hostilities lose their protected status only for a limited period of time, but the last category of individuals loses it ‘as long as they remain members’, and this membership renders them lawful targets ‘even before he or she first carries out a hostile act’.¹¹⁴\n\nAfter it was stated in the Official Commentary that the military commander does not need to have personal knowledge, it was argued that even if there is a ‘slight doubt’, additional information shall be obtained.¹¹⁵ By supporting it, Rogers points out that ‘[i]n the event of doubt about the nature of the target, an attack should not be carried out, with a possible exception where failure to prosecute the attack would put attacking forces in immediate danger’.¹¹⁶ However, this approach is challenged by some states, which claim that the determination should be ‘substantial doubt’¹¹⁷ to suspend an attack and require supplementary information. In the same vein, various authors claimed that conducting military operations without having a doubt on the nature of a target is not a reasonable expectation in the fog of war.¹¹⁸ From this perspective, there is always some doubt as an inherent characteristic of combat. On the other hand, the present author thinks that the Official Commentary should be interpreted as the aim of a commander. By stating the ‘slight doubt’ requirement, the commentary obligates them to take better precautions even if it is possible to erase this doubt. This is approved by military practice, in which attacks are cancelled when combatants are not ‘certain’¹¹⁹ or ‘100 percent sure of their aiming point’.¹²⁰ According to Parks, the US achieved this level of accuracy during the Linebacker II campaign by constantly confirming the nature of targets, implementing rules set by the Strategic Air Command, and issuing bomb damage assessments after each attack.¹²¹ Despite the fact that such high-level precautions sometimes pose substantial risks to the combatants’ lives, he acknowledges that they are important not only in terms of legality but also for achieving military and political objectives.¹²² By considering such positive outcomes, a commander should be sure enough that he/she made reasonable efforts to verify the nature of the target in cyberspace.¹²³\n\n113.     "The Military Law and the Law of War Review, Vol. 61 No. 1\n\nLastly, the dual nature of cyber systems might cause an attacker to identify only one particular part of the target as military, and the determination of other parts may remain unclear. At this point, cyber attack should be limited to that component, which is military in nature.¹²⁴ If it is not possible, then the attack should be cancelled. However, this should not be equated with being ‘perfectly familiar with the network’¹²⁵ since such an interpretation is not appropriate with the term ‘feasible’.\n\n## 3.2 Choice of cyber means and methods\n\nAfter the nature of the target is verified, the next step will be to compose an operational plan that will have a minimum effect on civilians. At this point, it is stated in Article 57 (2)(a)(ii) of the AP-I that members of the armed forces should ‘take all feasible precautions in the choice of means and methods of attack with a view to avoiding, and in any event to minimising, incidental loss or civilian life, injury to civilians and damage to civilian objects’. This means that even if an attack is proportionate, parties to the conflict should be careful in their choice of means and methods in order to minimize the effects of attacks as much as possible while still aiming to obtain maximum military advantage. At this point, an attacking party should produce a plan that promises to give the most efficient operational and legal results.¹²⁶\n\nIt is important to define ‘cyber means’ and ‘methods’. Cyber means are defined as ‘cyber weapons and their associated cyber systems’¹²⁷ in the Tallinn Manual. At this point, cyber weapons are kinds of cyber means, but the latter includes a broader category. Cyber methods, on the other hand, are defined as ‘the cyber tactics, techniques, and procedures by which hostilities are conducted’.¹²⁸ Whilst cyber means are concerned with which tools should be employed to carry out cyber operations, cyber methods are concerned with how these operations should be carried out.¹²⁹ Based on this viewpoint, while botnets are a type of cyber means, the DDoS attack that is conducted by botnets can be considered a type of cyber method.¹³⁰\n\nThere is no weapon or method that is specifically prohibited in the provision. It only obliges parties to take feasible precautions by choosing appropriate means and methods; thereby, a commander will not be responsible for causing civilian harm. However, the rule does not require parties to choose means and methods that may decrease their expected military advantage.¹³¹ Even if alternative means and methods are not used because of this concern, a planned cyber attack must abide by other principles such as distinction and proportionality.¹³² On the other hand, if choosing different means and methods may change the degree of damage by producing ‘equivalent effects’ upon the target, then alternative means or methods shall be selected.¹³³ A facility where armed forces of a belligerent party conduct cyber attacks against the enemy,\n\n¹²⁴.     "The application of the principle of precautions to cyber operations 21\n\nfor example, can be attacked by kinetic means. However, this may result in civilian deaths who live in the vicinity of the facility. At this point, if an attacking party has available means to conduct a cyber attack, it shall use them against the system or computers in the facility to stop belligerent attacks. Additionally, military personnel’s expertise with those new technologies is crucial. The concern was raised in the Eritrea-Ethiopia Claims Commission. Even though Eritrea refused Ethiopia’s allegations that some of its aircraft intentionally attacked civilians, the inexperience of Eritrean pilots in using ‘computerized aiming systems’, which led to the failure to target military objectives, was held as a violation of Article 57 of the AP-I.¹³⁴ Lastly, a ‘target list’ can be prepared and constantly reviewed by belligerent parties in order to determine which type of weapon should be used to decrease civilian harm by considering the characteristics of the target.¹³⁵ For example, the bombardment of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East (UNRWA) compound by the Israeli Armed Forces, which resulted in extensive damage and endangered the lives of many civilians, was accepted as reckless conduct and a violation of Article 57(2)(a)(ii) of the AP-I since it was executed while being aware of its importance for civilians.¹³⁶ However, in the Vietnam War, the US employed fragmentation bombs that had limited effects on the target to execute attacks against anti-aircraft batteries; since these batteries were located inside dikes, the army tried to refrain from damaging them.¹³⁷\n\nThe accuracy and range of weapons also have a particular importance in the execution of attacks.¹³⁸ If a target can be destroyed by accurate weapons, then it does not make sense to use dumb bombs or other means whose effects may not be calculated properly or limited. In this sense, the US practice in the Linebacker II campaign is important. During the campaign, the B-52s that have wide-range effects were employed because of weather conditions and the limited number of the more precise weapons.¹³⁹ But to keep the collateral damage to a minimum, the B-52s were used against targets that were either sufficiently large or in military-industrial complexes.¹⁴⁰ Other objectives requiring pinpoint strikes, such as bridges and railroad yards, were hit by more precise weapons when weather conditions permitted, which was limited to 12 hours during the 12-day campaign.¹⁴¹\n\nAs such practice in a highly interconnected battle arena demonstrates, cyber means and weapons should be used against adversaries while always considering their accuracy and range. When it would not be possible to precisely damage a cyber target that is interconnected with a civilian network, they should be used against military cyber networks, or at least those networks whose destruction does not have a significant impact on civilians. In this manner, a cyber mean can be designed to affect only a specific type of system, as it was in the Stuxnet incident, in which malware only affected the SCADA systems.\n\n¹³⁴.     "The Military Law and the Law of War Review, Vol. 61 No. 1\n\nThe employment of this type of smart malware having the capability of ‘system-fencing’ is recommended in the ICRC Report.¹⁴² The term refers to malware that is able to ‘recognize the environment it finds itself in and then execute itself only if the target system precisely matches that environment’.¹⁴³ Recent events demonstrate that states follow this trend by using precise cyber means.¹⁴⁴ At this point, the Russia-Ukraine War is of particular importance, and it should be carefully examined.\n\nIn the report prepared by Microsoft (the Microsoft Report), it is claimed that:\n\nRussian cyber tactics in the war have differed from those deployed in the NotPetya attack against Ukraine in 2017. That attack used ‘wormable’ destructive malware that could jump from one computer domain to another and hence cross borders into other countries. Russia has been careful in 2022 to confine destructive ‘wiper software’ to specific network domains inside Ukraine itself. But the recent and ongoing destructive attacks themselves have been sophisticated and more widespread than many reports recognize. And the Russian army is continuing to adapt these destructive attacks to changing war needs, including by coupling cyberattacks with the use of conventional weapons.¹⁴⁵\n\nThis passage raises two concerns. First, which types of cyber means are used? Second, excluding other considerations such as political or military ones, why did the Russians allegedly employ such means in an armed conflict while adhering to the LOAC?\n\nAs an answer to the first question, the Microsoft Report lists cyber means that were used or are in use in the Russia-Ukraine War:\n\n1. WhisperGate/WhisperKill\n2. FoxBlade, aka HermeticWiper\n3. DesertBlade\n4. CaddyWiper\n5. Lasainraw, aka IsaacWiper\n6. FiberLake, aka DoubleZero\n7. SonicVote, aka HermeticRansom\n8. Industroyer2\n\nAccording to the report, numbers 1, 2, 3 and 4 are ‘all malware families that overwrite data and render machines unbootable’; number 6 is a ‘.NET capability being used for data deletion’; number 7 is a ‘file encryptor sometimes used together with FoxBlade’; and number 8 ‘specifically targets operational technology to achieve physical effects in industrial production and processes’.¹⁴⁶ Even though the Microsoft Report does not give detail about number 5, another report states that it deletes data from physical and logical drives, though its impact is limited.¹⁴⁷ Except for number 8, the effects\n\n¹⁴².     "The application of the principle of precautions to cyber operations 23\n\nof all malware are limited to cyberspace. This brings an important issue to the surface. Even though the debate exists, operations causing such damage do not constitute attacks in terms of *lex lata*. Therefore, it would not be possible to apply Article 57 (2)(a)(ii) to those malwares since the rule encompasses means of warfare that are ‘used, designed, or intended to be used to conduct a cyber attack’.¹⁴⁸ Then the question would be why Russia needs to employ such discriminatory cyber means.\n\nFrom the present author’s perspective, the war demonstrated that the key benefit of using cyber means in warfare is their adaptability, instead of previous assumptions that cyber operations provide a belligerent party an advantage owing to their low cost or non-attributability. As stated in the report, Russia adapted such means to ‘changing war needs’.¹⁴⁹ This adaptation should be seen from two perspectives: cyber and kinetic. The former is important from a technical standpoint, and the latter is important from a legal standpoint, but both of them need to be examined because of their importance from a military standpoint.\n\nEven though it does not have a direct relationship with the legality of cyber means in terms of Article 57(2)(a)(ii), the technical standing point is important to understand why parties adopt cyber means in armed conflicts. Every new step in technology has the potential to threaten the kinetic weapon supremacy of an adversary. For example, the invention of a new type of surface-to-air missile system can erase the advantage of the adversary’s aircraft, and the attacking party needs to make a huge investment to improve its aircraft and produce new ones to establish a new squadron. On the other hand, the adaptability of cyber means makes it possible for past used malware to escape from such quick elimination. By adding some extra codes, a cyber weapon can be adjusted based on a new type of cyber security measure, and such modification can turn it into a new type of weapon. As stated by the ICRC, ‘it is possible for offensive cyber capabilities to be reverse-engineered or repurposed so that they can be reused. This is also the case for some traditional weapon systems, but the technical characteristics of cyberspace raise these concerns in a unique manner’.¹⁵⁰ This uniqueness has been and continues to be demonstrated in the Russia-Ukraine War. Numerous reports claim that Russia used or is using malware by modifying previously used ones. In other words, cyber security updates also bring updates to those malwares, and they are adapted to changing needs in the cyber environment. For example, AcidRain, a wiper malware used to disrupt the VIASAT satellite, shares some characteristics with VPNFilter, a kind of malware used by Russia-backed cyber-organized groups in 2018.¹⁵¹ Also, such modifications do not have to take a long time. Shortly after the intrusion of WhisperGate into Ukrainian systems and its detection by cyber security companies, Russia altered it and developed a new type of malware, Hermeticwiper, that ‘has some similarities to the earlier WhisperGate’.¹⁵² This shows that detecting malware and taking defensive measures against it do not make such malware useless, but certain parts of the codes can still be used by belligerents to improve their cyber capabilities owing to their adaptability.\n\n¹⁴⁸.     "The Military Law and the Law of War Review, Vol. 61 No. 1\n\n![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)\nFigure 1 The timeline shows how Russia adapted cyber means to kinetic operations $^{153}$\n\nFrom a legal standpoint, when Russia employs cyber means of warfare along with kinetic attacks, these means become subject to the LOAC principles. Figure 1 above, depicted by Microsoft, shows how critical infrastructures are subject to cyber operations as the Russian tanks roll toward cities. Additionally, the fact that certain facilities, which are being physically attacked, were subject to cyber operations, demonstrates that the coordination is not general but rather as specific as possible. As a result, every operation that is part of an attack has to be evaluated within the meaning of the LOAC, and this necessitates evaluating the cyber means stated above to be employed by respecting relevant rules, including the principle of precautions.\n\nWhile choosing cyber methods, the first relevant factor is the timing of the attack to minimize collateral damage.[154] During World War II, Allied Forces conducted attacks on military factories at times when there were a minimum number of civilian workers present.[155] In that vein, for example, while carrying out cyber attacks against dual-use objects, the belligerent party may execute them at night or early in the morning when the targets are not intensively used by civilians.\n\n153. Microsoft, 'Special Report: Ukraine - An Overview of Russia's Cyberattack Activity in Ukraine' (2022) 8.\n154. J-F Quéguiner, 'Precautions under the Law Governing the Conduct of Hostilities' (2006) 88 International Review of the Red Cross 793, 800.\n155.
