    "The application of the principle of precautions to cyber operations 25\n\nThe second relevant criterion is the location of the target. If a target is located in a place that is mostly used by civilians and there is a significant level of risk of harm occurring, the attacker shall use the most accurate weapons available or must refrain from conducting such an attack.¹⁵⁶ At this point, there is a discussion on whether the Internet can be held as a lawful target because, while it might make an effective contribution to the military capacity of the enemy, it is mostly used by civilians. Even though it is argued that if an attacking party believes that it can get enough military advantage, a cyber attack against the Internet is permissible,¹⁵⁷ another opinion accepts the Internet as a civilian object and prohibits such an attack.¹⁵⁸ According to the latter opinion, even if it is intended to carry out a cyber attack against the Internet, it should be limited to ‘individual networks, servers, routers, links, and other computer facilities that are used for military purposes and which are likely to be connected to the Internet’.¹⁵⁹ By accepting the latter interpretation, the present author considers that if it is possible to considerably limit the effects of the attack, especially by considering the dual nature of cyberspace, then an attack may be conducted. If not, it will be in breach of the rule.\n\nWhilst some authors argue that the choice of means and methods only come onto the scene when there is a similar advantage,¹⁶⁰ the present author thinks that the criteria should not be applied strictly. As stated by Borghard and Lonergan while discussing coercion in cyberspace, the attacking party tries to apply less harmful ways, such as disruptive operations rather than destructive ones, in order to better negotiate at later stages since the system may be restored more easily when the former type of means are used.¹⁶¹ At this point, the belligerent party should choose the type of means or methods to achieve the intended outcomes by considering the post-conflict situation.¹⁶² There is no doubt that a large number of civilian deaths will prolong the conflict, even if the attacks are perfectly legal. The bombing of Radio-Television of Serbia by NATO, which sparked so many debates about the legality of the campaign, may be an example of the adverse impact of such conduct. To Kolb, even if the station can be assumed as a military objective, it was repaired in three hours, and 16 civilians were killed because of the attack.¹⁶³ By taking lessons from this example, it can be stated that belligerent parties should always consider alternatives, even if a designed cyber attack seems lawful. In such a case, disrupting broadcasting by cyber operation might produce better consequences, even though it seems that destruction promises more advantage. In these kinds of situations, perpetrators should always keep the humanitarian aims of the LOAC in mind.\n\n¹⁵⁶.     "The Military Law and the Law of War Review, Vol. 61 No. 1\n\n## 3.3 The rule of proportionality in precautions\n\nIt is stated in Article 57(2) of the AP-I that:\n\n(a) those who plan or decide upon an attack shall:\n(iii) refrain from deciding to launch any attack which may be expected to cause incidental loss of civilian life, injury to civilians, damage to civilian objects, or a combination thereof, which would be excessive in relation to the concrete and direct military advantage anticipated;\n\n(b) an attack shall be cancelled or suspended if it becomes apparent that the objective is not a military one or is subject to special protection or that the attack may be expected to cause incidental loss of civilian life, injury to civilians, damage to civilian objects, or a combination thereof, which would be excessive in relation to the concrete and direct military advantage anticipated.\n\nWhile the former provision comes into scene at the planning level, the latter concerns the execution stage. However, both of these provisions have similar meanings by prohibiting attacks conducted against a legitimate target if it seems that ‘excessive’ collateral damage will occur, whether the cyber attack is being planned or has already been planned.¹⁶⁴ At this point, there should be a balance between military advantage and civilian harm.\n\n## 3.3.1 Military advantage\n\nThe advantage should be military in nature rather than merely moral, political or financial.¹⁶⁵ For example, conducting cyber attacks against specific sectors of a country, such as the oil industry, which is vital for Arab countries, by considering that such an operation against ‘war-sustaining objects’ will decrease the military effort of an enemy is not appropriate since ‘almost every civilian activity might be construed by the enemy as indirectly sustaining the war effort’ as stated by Dinstein.¹⁶⁶ Also, it is stated in the Official Commentary that this type of advantage can only be gained by the annihilation of an enemy or gaining ground; the transformation of the notion of war, however, changed this paradigm.¹⁶⁷ While the former can be categorized as an overstatement, the latter seems to be an understatement. Hence, as a moderate approach, the HPCR Manual Commentary points out that ‘any consequence of an attack which directly enhances friendly military operations or hinders those of the enemy’¹⁶⁸ should be included within the ambit of military advantage.\n\nCyber attacks should be assessed as a whole while aiming to obtain military advantage.¹⁶⁹ As stated by Fenrick and approved by declarations of numerous states, proportionality calculations cannot be made on either ‘a bullet-by-bullet basis’ or ‘the basis of attacks on individual military objectives’.¹⁷⁰ Furthermore, when the army launches concerted or coordinated cyber attacks, it may be impossible or impractical for every\n\n¹⁶⁴. Boothby (fn 158) 125–27.\n¹⁶⁵. HPCR Manual Commentary 45.\n¹⁶⁶. Y Dinstein, *The Conduct of Hostilities under the Law of International Armed Conflict* (Cambridge University Press, 2004) 87.\n¹⁶⁷. Sandoz, Swinarski and Zimmermann (eds) (fn 3) para 2218.\n¹⁶⁸. HPCR Manual Commentary 45.\n¹⁶⁹. Henckaerts and Doswald-Beck (fn 42) 49.\n¹⁷⁰. Ibid; WJ Fenrick, ‘Targeting and Proportionality during the NATO Bombing Campaign against Yugoslavia’ (2001) 12 European Journal of International Law 489, 499.\n\n© 2023 The Author\n\nJournal compilation © 2023 Edward Elgar Publishing Ltd\n\nDownloaded from https://www.elgaronline.com/ at 07/16/2025 08:36:46PM\n\nvia University College London (UCL)",
    "The application of the principle of precautions to cyber operations 27\n\nmember of the armed forces to make proper calculations.¹⁷¹ At this point, the planning stage has significant importance, and an attack should be judged by looking at the bigger picture. Although it was claimed that people who give an order will bear responsibility rather than those who execute the attack in such a case, if it is apparent that the targeted network is civilian in nature after the attack is initiated, it should be cancelled or a confirmation should be demanded by the perpetrator from higher ranks in light of changing circumstances.¹⁷² Lastly, assessing a cyber attack as a whole should not be interpreted as having a purpose to obtain military advantage by taking the ‘full context of a war strategy’ into account.¹⁷³ Otherwise, all cyber attacks, whether they incur excessive civilian damages or not, can be deemed legal in defiance of the aims of the LOAC.\n\n## 3.3.2 Collateral damage\n\nCollateral damage can be described as an ‘incidental loss of civilian life, injury to civilians and damage to civilian objects or other protected objects or a combination thereof, caused by an attack on a lawful target’.¹⁷⁴ At this point, collateral damage occurs while conducting cyber attacks against military targets without deliberately targeting civilians and civilian property.\n\nCollateral damage includes both the direct and indirect effects of a cyber attack. While the former type of effects are those that ‘are the immediate, first order consequence of a military action (weapons employment results, etc.), unaltered by intervening events or mechanisms’;¹⁷⁵ the latter type of effects are ‘the delayed or displaced second-, third-, and higher-order consequences of action, created through intermediate events or mechanisms’.¹⁷⁶ Since cyber operations are carried out at the logical layer of cyberspace, their first-order effects have an impact on data, programs, or software; nevertheless, such effects are not included in the aforementioned definition of collateral damage.¹⁷⁷ Yet, ‘indirect effects may be aimed at the other layers of cyberspace, or at creating other higher-order effects in other domains’, and thereby such effects can raise the level of collateral damage.¹⁷⁸ Therefore, the inclusion of indirect effects in the concept of collateral harm is crucial. However, due to the complexity involved in calculating second- or higher-order effects, such an inclusion also poses a significant challenge in cyberspace. As acknowledged in the Allied Doctrine:\n\nSince cyberspace is a global domain, there is a risk of COs [cyberspace operations] having an impact outside the joint operations area. COs can create undesired effects on our own\n\n¹⁷¹. Quéguiner (fn 154) 804.\n¹⁷². Ibid at 804–805.\n¹⁷³. Joint Targeting School Student Guide (Joint Targeting School 2017) 15.\n¹⁷⁶. Ibid.\n¹⁷⁷. NATO (fn 59) 17, para 2.27.\n¹⁷⁸. Ibid. For example, there are two known examples in which the indirect effects of ransomware resulted in patients’ deaths. See J Silomon, ‘The Düsseldorf Cyber Incident’ (Institute for Peace Research and Security Policy, 30 September 2020), available at <https: en=\"\" ifsh.de=\"\" news-detail=\"\" newsdestail=\"\" wwws-etal.org=\"\"> (accessed 30 March 2023); K Paulsen, M Evans and R McMillan, ‘A Hospital Hit by Hackers, a Baby in Distress: The Case of the First Alleged Ransomware Death’ (Wall Street Journal, 30 September 2021), available at <https: articles=\"\" ransomware-hackers-hospital-first-alleged-death-11633008116=\"\" www.wsj.com=\"\"> (accessed 30 March 2023).\n\n© 2023 The Author\n\nJournal compilation © 2023 Edward Elgar Publishing Ltd\n\nDownloaded from https://www.elgaronline.com/ at 07/16/2025 08:36:46PM\n\nvia University College London (UCL)</https:></https:>",
    "The Military Law and the Law of War Review, Vol. 61 No. 1\n\nforces and other entities, who are part of, or not part of, the mission. This risk, as with similar risks in other domains, is factored into the planning.¹⁷⁹\n\nEven though it is not necessary to make certain calculations, effects which are too remote or beyond the scope of reasonable certainty will not cause any responsibility for combatants.¹⁸⁰ Lastly, collateral damage does not contain minor effects such as stress, irritation or inconvenience.¹⁸¹ All cyber attacks might cause stress or inconvenience to some extent, but that does not make them illegal.\n\n## 3.3.3 Excessive collateral damage\n\nBelligerent parties should always consider whether the expected military advantage is proportionate compared to the anticipated collateral damage. At this point, the terms ‘extensive’ and ‘excessive’ should be differentiated. In the Official Commentary, it was argued that conducting attacks against lawful targets should not create ‘extensive destruction of civilian objects’¹⁸² despite the fact that there is no reference to such a limitation in the Additional Protocols. The collateral damage can be justified even if it is at the ‘extensive’ level on the condition that the nominated target is important enough. Although civilian casualties are ‘regrettable and tragic consequences of the war’, those losses do not ‘in themselves establish liability … under international law’ as stated by the Eritrea-Ethiopia Claims Commission.¹⁸³\n\nExcessiveness cannot be determined by approaching it as a mathematical formula, despite the fact that ‘[f]ifty civilians killed for one suspected combatant’ is given as a ‘textbook example of a violation of the proportionality principle’ by some authors.¹⁸⁴ However, as stated in the NATO Bombing Report:\n\nIt is much easier to formulate the principle of proportionality in general terms than it is to apply it to a particular set of circumstances because the comparison is often between unlike quantities and values. One cannot easily assess the value of innocent human lives as opposed to capturing a particular military objective.¹⁸⁵\n\nHence, excessiveness should be evaluated depending upon the comparison between two values, namely, collateral damage and military advantage. Although it is hard to estimate excessiveness in cyberspace and to prevent it, there are methods to make a reasonable assessment. It is stated in the Allied Doctrine that:\n\nCOs [cyberspace operations] will be conducted according to the operation plan. As such, SCEPVA [Sovereign Cyber Effects Provided Voluntarily by Allies], when authorised, might give the commander alternative options to create effects. These options are integrated,\n\n¹⁷⁹. NATO (fn 59) 25, para 3.28 (explanation added).\n¹⁸⁰. HPCR Manual Commentary, 92.\n¹⁸¹. Ibid at 34.\n¹⁸². Sandoz, Swinarski and Zimmermann (eds) (fn 3) para 2218.\n¹⁸³.     "The application of the principle of precautions to cyber operations 29\n\ncoordinated and synchronised across force components to achieve objectives as efficiently as possible.¹⁸⁶\n\nTherefore, the military commander should use all available options to assess the effects of cyber attacks. At this point, the determination of the effects and excessiveness of an action will be based on the good faith of the combatant, its reasonableness and the circumstances in which the cyber attack is planned and executed.\n\n## 3.4 Effective warning\n\nIt is stated in Article 57(2)(c) of the AP-I that ‘effective advance warning shall be given of attacks which may affect the civilian population, unless circumstances do not permit’. The first appearance of this rule can be traced back to the Lieber Code, in which it was stated that:\n\nCommanders, whenever admissible, inform the enemy of their intention to bombard a place, so that the noncombatants, and especially the women and children, may be removed before the bombardment commences. But it is no infraction of the common law of war to omit thus to inform the enemy. Surprise may be a necessity.¹⁸⁷\n\nAs it can be observed from the article, if a party plans to conduct a surprise cyber attack, it does not need to give any warning so as not to endanger the success of the operation.¹⁸⁸ Surprise may be necessary in some cases, such as when there is a risk of a pre-emptive cyber attack or the exposure of a broader campaign.¹⁸⁹ The Tallinn Manual illustrates this by saying that:\n\nConsider, for example, a cyber operation involving placement of a kill-switch into the target computer’s control system, to be activated on the occurrence of some future event or after the passage of a specified period. A warning that would give the enemy an opportunity to locate and neutralise the device need not be given.¹⁹⁰\n\nTherefore, giving warning is limited to appropriate circumstances since an attacker may have special reasons that justify not giving any warning.¹⁹¹ A relevant consideration could be the equation comparing the level of military advantage between situations in which giving occurs and those in which it does not. If the gap justifies civilian harm, then the attacking party does not need to give a warning in advance.\n\nIf it is expected that the cyber attack will exclusively affect civilian objects and not have any impact on civilians, then giving warning will not be necessary.¹⁹² By approving this point, the Australian Military Manual states that the warning can be directed at civilians, who bear the dangers posed by an intended attack, or at responsible authorities.¹⁹³ In that vein, if harm to civilians is expected, then they can be warned in many ways through\n\n¹⁸⁶.     "The Military Law and the Law of War Review, Vol. 61 No. 1\n\ncyberspace, such as emails and websites, or an attacking party may choose to warn only civilian authorities by these methods.¹⁹⁴ There is no necessity to issue a warning in a formal way.¹⁹⁵ If it is effective, it can be conveyed by any means that are available to the attacking party, such as in a written or verbal way.¹⁹⁶ Sending voice recordings or text messages through WhatsApp, for instance, might be a feasible precaution if it is deemed to be effective.\n\nThe term ‘effective’ is not clarified, neither in the AP-I nor in its commentary. Even though the Australian Military Manual suggests adopting ‘commonsense’ to achieve effectiveness, this does not clarify the notion but adds extra blurriness to it.¹⁹⁷ On the other hand, the term ‘effective’ is defined in the dictionary as ‘producing a decided, decisive, or desired effect’.¹⁹⁸ Based on this definition, it can at least be said that in order for a warning to be effective, it should aim to reduce collateral damage to a minimum. To accomplish this, the content of the warning should be reasonably clear and specific so that civilians have a chance to secure themselves from the effects of an attack.¹⁹⁹ Both of these terms should be determined based on the context. In terms of clarity, rather than giving technical details, belligerent parties may underline the effects of cyber attacks and provide guidelines to civilians on how to protect themselves from such effects. In terms of specificity, there is no requirement to give a specific warning for every situation; the warning may be general in a way that provides a list of cyber objectives that might be targeted.²⁰⁰ Overall, there is no one correct method to issuing effective warnings, but they should be tailored to diverse scenarios to protect civilians.\n\nWarnings can be conducted through an enemy if it makes the warning more effective.²⁰¹ However, such a warning can also be used as a ruse of war. For example, ‘a false announcement of a cyber attack affecting dual-use systems might prove militarily useful in causing the enemy to take its military assets off-line’.²⁰² Nevertheless, if it is expected that such a warning causes civilians to ignore future real warnings and to put them in danger, then this will be prohibited.²⁰³ Further, the belligerent party should not give a warning in order to spread terror among civilians.²⁰⁴ As stated in Article 51(2) of the AP-I, ‘[a]cts or threats of violence the primary purpose of which is to spread terror among the civilian population are prohibited’. For this reason, warnings given through cyberspace that aim to ‘frighten or cause panic among residents or compel them to leave their homes for reasons other than their safety’ are forbidden.²⁰⁵ Although there is always a danger for civilians to be exposed to fake news via the Internet without the knowledge of the attacking party, it is also their obligation to search for the truth.\n\n194.     "The application of the principle of precautions to cyber operations 31\n\n# 3.5 The least danger rule\n\nIt is stated in Article 57(3) of the AP-I that:\n\nWhen a choice is possible between several military objectives for obtaining a similar military advantage, the objective to be selected shall be that the attack on which may be expected to cause the least danger to civilian lives and to civilian objects.\n\nFrom the perspective of this article, if a commander has more than one option, then the rule can be applicable. Therefore, this rule is also known as ‘the lesser of two evils’.²⁰⁶ The rationale behind the article is simple: While a commander is trying to get the maximum effect on the military capacity of the enemy, he/she should seek an option which has minimum effect on civilians. The example given in the Official Commentary is that ‘[i]nstead of attacking railway stations, which are usually located in towns, the railway lines were hit at crucial points, but away from inhabited areas; the same action was taken with respect to roads’.²⁰⁷ By analogy, it can be stated that cyber attacks should be conducted against specific networks of electricity distribution facilities rather than the whole power station.²⁰⁸ However, the rule comes into scene when two different options promise military advantage at the same level.²⁰⁹ Otherwise, the attack is subject to other provisions and principles, i.e., proportionality.\n\nThere are two critical discussions to have while inflicting the least amount of harm on civilians and civilian property. First, whether or not causing harm to civilians and civilian property is equally important. At this point, while discussing the Kosovo Conflict, General Clark states that ‘[w]e weren’t going to disregard risks to civilians but the alternative to taking risks with property damage was that we might ultimately have to put our troops in on the ground’.²¹⁰ From this example, it seems that objects have less value than civilian lives in practice. However, cyber operations are more likely to have effects on objects than on people. Therefore, the relevant discussion may be whether all objects have the same value in cyberspace. At this point, Henderson offers to determine the value of objects by various factors such as ‘the “utility” of the object, the objects “replace-ability”, and the cost of replacement’.²¹¹ In that vein, in terms of utility, it may be preferable to have an impact on financial records rather than medical data in cyberspace. The second discussion is whether belligerent parties put civilians at greater risk than their own troops. Although some states and scholars adopt the opinion that the security of armed forces should be included in military advantage,²¹² another approach holds that the armed forces must accept the risks posed by combat actions, and those risks should not be borne by civilians.²¹³ The present author considers that an attacking party who conducts cyber attacks against an enemy already minimizes the dangers of combat for its own troops because of their remoteness\n\n²⁰⁶.     "The Military Law and the Law of War Review, Vol. 61 No. 1\n\nfrom the battlefield. Therefore, it should not disregard civilian damage by claiming force protection.\n\nBeyond mere humanitarianism, it is a military reality to target legitimate objectives to the maximum extent while harming civilians to the minimum. Carnahan states that '[t]he wise military officer will try to concentrate firepower on key military objectives and to keep to a minimum the collateral damage not only for humanitarian reasons, but also because munitions that injure civilians are wasted munitions'.[214] When the humanitarian impacts of such 'wasted munitions' are considered along with their military value, it is a well-known fact that when civilian harm increases, the likelihood of success of the mission decreases, so belligerent parties should aim to put the least amount of risk on civilians if there is an opportunity to refrain from it while gaining a military advantage at the same level, or at least another option that significantly decreases the military advantage.[215]\n\n# 4 PRECAUTIONS AGAINST THE EFFECTS OF CYBER OPERATIONS\n\n## 4.1 General remarks\n\nIt is stated in Article 58 of the AP-I that:\n\nThe Parties to the conflict shall, to the maximum extent feasible:\n\n(a) without prejudice to Article 49 of the Fourth Convention, endeavour to remove the civilian population, individual civilians and civilian objects under their control from the vicinity of military objectives;\n\n(b) avoid locating military objectives within or near densely populated areas;\n\n(c) take the other necessary precautions to protect the civilian population, individual civilians and civilian objects under their control against the dangers resulting from military operations.\n\nThe rationale behind the article is to abstain from 'defensive tactics that unnecessarily increases civilian risk' by endangering civilians and civilian objects to the detrimental effects of military operations.[216] For this reason, belligerent parties should segregate their military objectives from civilians and civilian objectives; if this is not possible, they should at least protect these people and objects from the effects of cyber operations.[217]\n\nThe rule is applicable within the territory of the belligerent party, which is responsible for the protection of its nationals or people under its control.[218] However, this territorial application of the rule may pose a significant hurdle in cyberspace. Although it was claimed that 'all civilian cyber infrastructure and activities located in territory under the control of a party to the conflict are subject to this Rule', this approach cannot be applicable in cyberspace since it is almost impossible to control every civilian activity in this domain.[219] This follows a risk that a responsible government may claim\n\n214. BM Carnahan, 'Linebacker II and Protocol I: The Convergence of Law and Professionalism' (1982) 31 American University Law Review 868.\n215. Corn and Schoettler Jr (fn 3) 821.\n216. Ibid at 827.\n217. Jensen (fn 58) 212.\n218. Sandoz, Swinarski and Zimmermann (eds) (fn 3) para 2239.\n219. Tallinn Manual Rule 121 Cmt. para 8.\n\n© 2023 The Author\n\nJournal compilation © 2023 Edward Elgar Publishing Ltd\n\nDownloaded from https://www.elgaronline.com/ at 07/16/2025 08:36:46PM\n\nvia University College London (UCL)",
    "The application of the principle of precautions to cyber operations 33\n\nthat ‘it does not have authority over most of the cyber infrastructure due to the various legal regimes that exist within the nation’.²²⁰ At this point, the term ‘control’ refutes such a defence by obligating the party to protect civilians and civilian property by segregating civilian computer systems if it has a capacity to control these systems.²²¹ As a result, this obligation should not be applied by taking territorial concerns into account but rather by considering whether or not these systems are under the de facto control of a party.\n\nThese precautions are applicable as soon as they are ‘to the maximum extent feasible’. Although the term ‘feasible’ was explained in the first chapter, the Official Commentary further clarifies this term by noting that those measures should ‘not go beyond the point where the life of the population would become difficult or even impossible’.²²² Also, the Tallinn Manual explains the term ‘maximum extent’ in a way that it ‘emphasises the importance of taking the requisite measures’.²²³ According to one approach, those measures can be applied depending upon ‘the requirements of national defence’ as stated in the declaration of Austria.²²⁴ From this perspective, parties do not need to expose all of their military facilities, or to put them in a more dangerous position by considering the dictations of the national defence.²²⁵ This is explained in Official Records by the delegation of the Republic of Korea with the following words:\n\n[T]his provision does not constitute a restriction on a State’s military installations on its own territory. We consider that military facilities necessary for a country’s national defence should be decided on the basis of the actual needs and other considerations of that particular country. An attempt to regulate a country’s requirements and the fulfilment of those requirements in this connexion would not conform to actualities.²²⁶\n\nThis is a valid argument since, as described in the first chapter, the principle of precautions obligates parties to take measures when they are ‘practicable or practically possible’. For this reason, every country has to take precautions against the effects of cyber attacks within its own limits.\n\nWhile the term ‘constant care’ is not explicitly stated in the article, it is still a valid consideration which should be taken into account in order to alleviate risks to civilians and civilian property.²²⁷ At this point, Corn points three reasons why constant care should be taken in both active and passive precautions:²²⁸ First, there is no clear line between ‘attacking’ and ‘defending’ parties in terms of operational art since every armed force needs to conduct both types of operations in the conflict. Second, ‘constant care’ obliges all parties of an armed conflict to conduct their operations by taking civilian harm into account as well as seeking to gain military advantage. This obligation cannot be confined to the attacking party. Third, the exclusion of defending\n\n220. Jensen (fn 58) 214–15.\n221. Ibid.\n222.     "The Military Law and the Law of War Review, Vol. 61 No. 1\n\nforces from taking constant care may permit them to pose more risks to civilians as a defensive measure. When the nature of cyberspace is taken into account, the obligation becomes more important than conventional warfare since the domain has many more complexities than other areas.\n\nThese measures are similarly sampled in the ICRC Challenge Report and the Tallinn Manual while discussing feasible precautions against the effects of cyber attacks:\n\n[S]egregating military from civilian cyber infrastructure; segregating computer systems on which critical civilian infrastructure depends from the Internet; backing up important civilian data; making advance arrangements to ensure the timely repair of important computer systems; digitally recording important cultural or spiritual objects to facilitate reconstruction in the event of their destruction; and using anti-virus measures to protect civilian systems that might suffer damage or destruction during an attack on military cyber infrastructure.²²⁹\n\nThis is not an exhaustive list, and every situation may require different precautions to be taken.\n\n## 4.2 The segregation of civilian networks\n\nAs it is indicated above, Article 58(a) of the AP-I requires parties to ‘endeavour to remove the civilian population, individual civilians and civilian objects under their control from the vicinity of military objectives’. The obligation should be applied when there is an immediate danger to civilians, and they should be evacuated them from the territory ‘where the risk of attack is greatest’.²³⁰ Even if this measure brings some difficulty to civilians, it aims to protect them from greater suffering, and alternative accommodations should be provided.²³¹ If these measures are not achieved, this can be deemed forced displacement and a violation of international law.\n\nWhilst the rule seems applicable when traditional battlefield is taken into account, it still creates some problems. For example, the rule was opposed by Switzerland because of its geographical conditions, where most civilians live in valleys in which important military facilities are located due to the limited number of useful locations in the country, so it becomes very hard to segregate civilians and civilian objects from the proximity of these facilities.²³² The same hardship is applicable for some facilities that can be important for both civilians and military personnel, such as air traffic control centres and power generation plants.²³³\n\nOn the other hand, the application of the rule in cyberspace brings more difficulty than in traditional domains. Civilian infrastructures are used for almost all cyber operations, and most of them have a dual nature.²³⁴ As an example, how can civilians be removed from cloud technology, which is also used for military purposes?²³⁵ Nevertheless, it is argued in a legal assessment published by the US Department of Defence that ‘[w]here there is a choice … military systems should be kept separate from\n\n²²⁹.     "The application of the principle of precautions to cyber operations 35\n\ninfrastructures used for essential civilian purposes’.²³⁶ For example, parties to the conflict can build a separate cyber infrastructure in which only military communications travel through it, and locate dual-use cyber infrastructures separate from civilians.²³⁷ Although it can be claimed that situations may arise in which civilian and military networks cannot be segregated, state practice has started to follow a different pathway.²³⁸ It is stated by Walker that:\n\nIn cyberspace, State practice, particularly that of the United States, makes clear that it is feasible to separate purely military objectives from civilian objectives, at least up to a point. The United States military uses multiple, dedicated networks to conduct administrative, logistical and operational activities. The three best-known networks are the Non-Classified Internet Protocol Router Network (NIPRnet, which carries information classified up to and including Sensitive but Unclassified), Secret Internet Protocol Router Network (SIPRnet, which carries data classified up to and including the Secret level) and the Joint Worldwide Intelligence Communication System (JWICS carries data classified up to and including Top Secret/Sensitive Compartmented Information).²³⁹\n\nAs this example clearly shows, it is imperative to segregate the different types of networks, even if it can be costly.²⁴⁰ Otherwise, if the object makes an effective contribution and the segregation cannot be established, then the whole cyber infrastructure would be a lawful target.²⁴¹\n\nGovernmental and civilian data can be stored in the public cloud, despite the fact that this does not literally satisfy the criteria for segregation. However, the Russia-Ukraine War proved its usefulness in terms of reducing cyber dangers. The Ukrainian government moved an important part of the state’s digital infrastructure to the public cloud in preparation for Russian cyber operations against its governmental data center.²⁴² In this sense, cloud technology turns the disadvantage of cyber infrastructure’s interconnectedness into an advantage. As a more advanced example, the Estonian government established a ‘data embassy’ whose ‘resources are under Estonian state control, secured against cyberattacks or crisis situations with KSI [Keyless Signature Infrastructure] Blockchain technology, and are capable not only providing data backups, but also operating the most critical services’.²⁴³ The particular advantage of such precautions compared with network segregation is that they protect civilian data not only from cyber attacks but also from other types of crises that might occur within states’ borders, such as natural disasters or kinetic attacks.²⁴⁴\n\nIf such precautions impose a significant burden on the belligerent and are not feasible solutions, belligerent parties should search for other ways to shield civilian\n\n236.     "The Military Law and the Law of War Review, Vol. 61 No. 1\n\nnetworks against cyber operations.²⁴⁵ The pertinent precaution could be the establishment of ‘digital safe havens’ through agreements between belligerent parties; while some systems may be difficult to negotiate due to their potential assistance to the adversary’s military effort, other systems critical to civilian life may be easily agreed upon.²⁴⁶\n\n## 4.3 The location of military objectives\n\nIt is stated in Article 58(b) of the AP-I that belligerent parties should ‘avoid locating military objectives within or near densely populated areas’. From this perspective, parties to the conflict should refrain from locating both movable and immovable objects close to densely populated areas in order to protect civilians under their control.²⁴⁷ Nevertheless, the rule should not be limited to densely populated areas but also include ‘hospitals, cultural property, places of worship, prisoner of war camps, and other facilities which are entitled to specific protection’²⁴⁸ by refraining from locating cyber military objectives in or around them.\n\nWhile the applicability of the rule is understood in a physical sense, and social media or other similar civilian websites ‘cannot be equated with densely populated areas’, the rule obliges parties to take measures by considering cyber infrastructures which are physically located in the territory of a party.²⁴⁹ Therefore, for instance, army cyber commands should not be located in places where civilians or special protected objects can be put in danger. However, there is a significant hurdle to locating defence ministries in a place which is not close to densely populated areas. On the other hand, it is still possible for parties to exclude these kinds of facilities, which are military in nature but almost impossible to locate in isolated places, from the ambit of the attack through negotiation. Even if they cannot be attacked, it is possible for a party to conduct disruptive cyber operations against cyber infrastructures in these facilities. At this point, cyber operations give a unique opportunity to parties not to harm civilians but to still have an impact on the military capacity of their enemies.\n\n## 4.4 Other passive measures\n\nAs it is stated above, belligerent parties should ‘take the other necessary precautions to protect the civilian population, individual civilians and civilian objects under their control against the dangers resulting from military operations’ according to Article 58(c) of the AP-I. While there is no limit on the scope of the rule, the Official Commentary states that this rule should be applied to civilians by providing them with protective shelters, as well as to specially protected objects by providing trained personnel to limit damage to them.²⁵⁰ However, conflicting parties should take all feasible precautions by taking the gap-filling function of Article 58(c) into account.\n\n²⁴⁵.     "The application of the principle of precautions to cyber operations 37\n\nIt has been claimed that while providing shelter may seem rational in traditional domains, its application in cyberspace is still unknown.²⁵¹ However, there are some measures which are applicable to cyberspace by analogy. For example, civilians might be supported by providing them with software products such as anti-virus programs that limit the damage from cyber attacks, detecting civilian cyber systems in order to warn people in case of intrusion attempts, providing them technical assistance when their computer systems are harmed, providing a back-up system to store civilian data, blocking particular IP addresses which pose risks to civilian systems, and keeping ready a system that makes it possible to disconnect an entire country from the Internet when all measures are exhausted.²⁵²\n\nWhile the title of Article 58 includes ‘attacks’, paragraph (c) clearly states that some precautions should be applied to operations. Although Jensen admits the ambiguity of this situation, he argues that countries which are not parties to the AP-I have responsibility arising from this provision for those acts that reach ‘attack’ threshold.²⁵³ In the Tallinn Manual, even though the majority of experts stated that the rule is applicable only to cyber attacks because of the title of the article and the non-existence of customary law, the minority focused on the wording of paragraph (c) by accepting cyber operations within the ambit of this rule.²⁵⁴ Therefore, the minority view kept the threshold lower, determined disruptive operations to be covered by this rule, and obligated parties to take precautions against the effects of these operations.²⁵⁵ However, both parties have a common understanding on the non-application of the rule to ‘mere inconvenience or irritation’.²⁵⁶\n\nThere is no clear-cut answer on which precautions should be taken within the ambit of Article 58(c), since the provision serves as a gap-filler in the article. Despite the fact that it did not receive much attention in the past because the suitability of other provisions for kinetic activities made them more visible than paragraph (c), their relative unsuitability for cyber operations rendered this clause more important. At this point, the implementation of the norm in cyberspace has already begun to be shaped by the practices of both state and non-state actors, and this trend seems to be continuing and getting better. For example, the US government has begun to warn private entities when they are subjected to transborder cyber attacks and has provided them with cyber tools and training to combat those attacks.²⁵⁷ Furthermore, the Security Service of Ukraine informs civilians about cyber threats and what measures to take in order to avoid them.²⁵⁸ As a recent innovative example, the ICRC has been conducting research on creating a ‘digital emblem’ for the past two years in order to enable the identification of objects, systems, or networks that cannot be subject to cyber attacks.²⁵⁹ Lastly, even though these are individual precautionary measures, the Russia-Ukraine War has also demonstrated how state and non-state entities can collaborate to\n\n251.     "The Military Law and the Law of War Review, Vol. 61 No. 1\n\nprotect civilians from the effects of cyber operations. The Microsoft Report highlights two examples of cyber security measures against Russian cyber activities:\n\nThe first has been the use of technology acquired from RiskIQ that identifies and maps organizational attack surfaces, including devices that are unpatched against known vulnerabilities and therefore are the most susceptible to attack. This information has been shared with the Ukrainian government free of charge to enable it to accelerate the strengthening of cyber-defenses. Ukrainian network defenders worked tirelessly with the constant support of the CERT UA within the government to use this information to protect computers across the country.\n\nThe second measure has been a wartime innovation pursued with the collaboration and support of the Ukrainian government. MSTIC recognized that Russian malware could be mitigated meaningfully by turning on a feature in Microsoft Defender called controlled folder access. This typically would require that IT administrators access devices across their organization, work made more difficult and potentially even dangerous in wartime conditions. The Ukrainian government therefore authorized Microsoft through special legal measures to act proactively and remotely to turn on this feature across devices throughout the government and across the country.²⁶⁰\n\nEvery effort having a purpose to minimize collateral damage is desired in cyberspace; the principle of precaution essentially relies on the processes but not the results.\n\n# 5 CONCLUSION\n\nNew technologies have changed the nature of armed conflict significantly, and this process increasingly continues. As one kind of these technologies, cyber operations have introduced significant challenges to the LOAC, but the most unique one is their capability to have a wide range of effects because of the interconnectedness of cyberspace. This article has endeavoured to determine the application of the principle of precautions to cyber operations by tilting the principle towards humanity by considering the natures of both the principle and cyberspace.\n\nFrom the standpoint of the principle of precautions, the Russia-Ukraine War exemplified an important phenomenon: public-private cooperation against adversarial cyber operations. Unlike traditional domains, private entities have a partial but critical level of control over cyberspace, and as a result of this distinctive feature of the current conflicts, the Ukrainian government collaborated with a technology giant, Microsoft.²⁶¹ This collaboration is emphasized in the Microsoft Report by stating that:\n\n[U]nlike the traditional threats of the past, cyber defenses rely on a unique level of public and private collaboration. The evolving threat landscape requires a whole-of-society approach. The private sector, particularly technology companies, are on the front lines of cyber and information attacks. Likewise, civil society organizations are key conveners that play a crucial role in engagement, sometimes are involved in cyber data analysis, and are often targets of these campaigns themselves.²⁶²\n\nBringing non-public entities into the equation in cyberspace, thereby putting more civilians in the balance, would enhance the ‘civilianization’ of armed conflicts, and this would inherently lean the principle of precaution on the side of humanity.\n\n²⁶⁰. Microsoft (fn 145) 9.\n²⁶¹. Ibid.\n²⁶².
